message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody used to treat multiple sclerosis, but it is associated with an increased risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is a rare brain infection caused by the JC virus. Patients who have previously been treated with immunosuppressive drugs or who have been infected with the JC virus may be at increased risk for PML. Parkinsonism, tuberculosis, and aplastic anemia are not associated with natalizumab use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Natalizumab can increase the risk of developing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a rare but serious brain infection. This is a known potential complication of treatment with natalizumab, and patients must be monitored carefully for signs and symptoms of PML. Parkinsonism, tuberculosis, and aplastic anemia are not known complications of natalizumab treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Natalizumab is known to increase the risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) in patients with previous exposure to the John Cunningham virus (JCV). Since the patient has multiple sclerosis and has had multiple exacerbations, she is likely to have been exposed to JCV and therefore at increased risk for PML. Parkinsonism, tuberculosis, and aplastic anemia are not known adverse effects of natalizumab.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Natalizumab is known to increase the risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a potentially fatal viral infection of the brain. This risk is increased in patients who have previously been treated with immunosuppressive therapy or who have been exposed to the JC virus. The patient’s history of multiple exacerbations and use of high-dose methylprednisone for treatment may increase her risk for PML. Parkinsonism, tuberculosis, and aplastic anemia are not associated with treatment with natalizumab.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Natalizumab is known to increase the risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a rare and serious brain infection. This risk is increased in patients who have had previous treatment with immunosuppressive medications, such as high-dose methylprednisone, which this patient has received. The other options are not associated with natalizumab treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Natalizumab is associated with an increased risk of developing an opportunistic infection called progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is caused by the JC virus. It is important to monitor patients receiving natalizumab for signs of PML, such as progressive neurologic deficits or new-onset cognitive problems. Parkinsonism is not a known adverse effect of natalizumab. Tuberculosis and aplastic anemia are also not associated with natalizumab use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Natalizumab can cause progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, which is a rare but serious complication. This risk is higher in patients who have been previously treated with immunosuppressant drugs or who have had prolonged natalizumab therapy. Parkinsonism, tuberculosis, and aplastic anemia are not common adverse effects of natalizumab.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Natalizumab is known to increase the risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) which is a rare but serious viral infection of the brain. Patients should be screened for the JC virus before starting treatment to assess their risk of PML. Parkinsonism, tuberculosis, and aplastic anemia are not associated with natalizumab.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Natalizumab is an immunosuppressive medication used for multiple sclerosis, but it increases the risk of developing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is a potentially fatal viral disease that affects the brain. This risk is higher in patients who have previously received immunosuppressive treatments or have the JC virus present in their blood. Parkinsonism, tuberculosis, and aplastic anemia are not related to the patient's current treatment or medical history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody used to treat multiple sclerosis. Its major side effect is progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) which is caused by John Cunningham virus (JC virus) infection. The patient is at increased risk for PML because she has had multiple exacerbations and has been treated with high doses of methylprednisone. Parkinsonism, tuberculosis, and aplastic anemia are not associated with natalizumab use.
